bioghist.p: Gerald Weales (b. 1925) is a theater scholar, critic, and Professor Emeritus of English at the University of Pennsylvania. He received his bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees from Columbia University. His books include The Jumping off Place: American Drama in the 1960s, American Drama since World War II, Canned Goods as Caviar, and Religion in Modern English Drama. For 25 years his theater reviews were published in Commonweal, and he has also published in many other journals, including the Nation, the Gettysburg Review, the Tulane Drama Review, the Quarterly of Film Radio and Television.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of typescript drafts and galleys of books written by Gerald Weales. Most of these drafts are only lightly annotated with copy edits and proofreaders's marks; the short stories are more heavily annotated. Book manuscripts include: American Drama Since World War II, Arthur Miller: Death of a Salesman, Religion in Modern English Drama, Canned Goods as Caviar, Tale for the Bluebird, and The Complete Plays of William Wycherly. Manuscripts of essays and chapters include: "Ruggles of Red Gap," "Steamboat Round the Bend,"" It's a Gift," and "Ronald Ribman: Artist of the Failure Clowns." Manuscripts of play and screenplays include: "Ethics, Incorporated," "The Hero at Home," "The Western Hero," and "The Hero and Homicide."

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
